_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Pumps, Compressors and Emergency Shutdown Vlaves and Internal Valves

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
AmeriGas Columbia Terminal - Facility Description

The AmeriGas Columbia terminal is a propane storage and distribution facility. The facility includes ten (10) above-ground storage tanks. Each Tank has 30,000 Gallons Water Capacity W.C each. Three (3) of the tanks are for butane service and the other seven (7) are for propane service. The maximum quantity of product in pounds that we can store on site of propane is 747,094 pounds and butane is 372,387 pounds. There are six (6) Compressors used to unload the rails cars. The terminal has a siding with eight (8) rail towers designed to hook to rail cars and unload product to storage tanks using a system of Compressors. Compressors withdraw propane vapors from the storage tank and compress them or increase their pressure and discharge into the rail cars to be unloaded. This process slightly decreases the pressure in the bulk storage tanks and increases the pressure in the rail cars. As a result, liquid propane flows from rail car to the bulk storage tanks. 

The terminal has four (4) Liquid Pumps and four (4) bulkheads. Using the loading pumps, transports are loaded at the terminal, when required. There are also five (5) Plant Wide Emergency Shutdown Buttons, three (3) electrical system shutdown buttons, and twelve (12) individual system pneumatic shutdown buttons that are strategically located throughout the terminal that are used to power off the electrical equipment including pumps, compressors and air compressors, pneumatically charged Emergency Shutdown Valves (ESVs) and internal valve. 

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policy

The same properties that make propane and butane valuable as a fuel also make it necessary to practice certain safety precautions in handling them to prevent leaks, spills and accidents. First and foremost, in our operations, efforts are undertaken to ensure employee and contractor safety while on site as well as to minimize the risk of exposure to the surrounding comm

unities. It is our company policy to adhere to all applicable federal, state and local rules and regulations. The Facility has Terminal Operations Supervisor who is able to immediately assist with a serious incident by contacting the emergency responders. AmeriGas also maintains an around the clock Emergency Communications Center (ECC), which handles all after-hours and emergency calls from around the country. The ECC has the ability to contact AmeriGas field personnel, as well as Chemtrec, on any type of incident encountered at any AmeriGas location or by AmeriGas customers. 

The site and company continually strive to improve operations performance including the prevention of incidents, injuries, and releases at the facility. Primary elements of this continuous improvement effort include making capital improvements to the facility as required, maintaining up to date procedures, and continual training of personnel in both regulatory and job specific subject matter. The integrity and reliability of major equipment, including pumps, compressors, pipelines, and storage tanks is assured through periodic inspection and preventive maintenance practices. The chemicals handled do not present significant internal corrosion hazards and corrosion to external surfaces of pipelines and storage tanks is minimized via inspection and painting programs.

As important as those previously mentioned items are, shutdown systems are also installed on site. Shutdown systems include remotely controlled, positive shutoff valves designed to shutdown affected equipment and isolate a problem once detected. Portable fire extinguishers are also available on site for employee use.

As a corporation, AmeriGas staffs a professional Safety Department at our Corporate Headquarters in King of Prussia, Pennsylvania. AmeriGas also has seven Regional Logistics Managers, a Terminal Operations Manager, a Safety and Technology Manager, and a Supply and Logistics Safety Manager strategically located through

out the United States. These safety professionals are able to immediately respond to a serious incident and provide technical expertise to emergency response agencies as needed at the scene of the incident. AmeriGas also maintains an around the clock Emergency Communications Center (ECC), which handles all after-hours and emergency calls from around the country. Located in Rocklin, California, the ECC has the ability to contact AmeriGas field personnel as well as Chemtrec on any type of incident encountered at an AmeriGas location or by AmeriGas customers.

This distribution and storage facility is subject to and abides by OSHAs Process Safety Management (PSM) rule for sites handling hazardous chemicals. In addition, the site complies with EPAs Accidental Release Prevention Rule and all other applicable federal, state, and local codes and regulations. 

All of our AmeriGas transport drivers have been thoroughly trained in the terminals loading and Emergency Action Plan procedures and many have also been trained using the National Propane Gas Associations (NPGA) Certified Employee Training Program (CETP).

Offsite Consequence Analysis Results

Worst Case Scenario

For flammables, vapor cloud explosion is specified as worst case scenario. Worst case scenario is analyzed by estimating distance to an overpressure endpoint of 1 psi resulting from vapor cloud explosion of a cloud containing largest quantity of regulated substance from a vessel or process pipe failure. Per CFR 68.25.b.1, For substances in a vessel, the greatest amount held in a vessel, taking into account administrative controls that limit the maximum quantity is the worst-case scenario.

The greatest amount of propane held is 30,000 Gallons or 110,000 lbs. The total quantity released was 110,000 lbs. The propane was assumed to disperse in the flammable range, encounter areas of sufficient congestion and confinement and result in a vapor cloud explosion.
Using EPA RMP Comp, the calculated worst-cas

e distance to 1 psi overpressure end point for vapor cloud explosion is 0.4 miles.

Assumption
RMP assumes meteorological conditions for the worst-case scenario of atmospheric stability class F (stable atmosphere) and wind speed of 1.5 meters per second (3.4 miles per hour). The ambient air temperature assumed is 25 deg C (77 deg F). TNT-equivalent model is used which assumes a yield factor of 10 percent.. 

Alternative Release Scenario

For the alternative release scenario, release from transfer hoses at the facility was chosen. The active mitigation devices were assumed to work as designed, limiting the release to the contents of the hose. The calculated distance to 1 psi overpressure endpoint for vapor cloud explosion is 0.02 miles.

Broken or burst propane loading hoses were determined to be the most common failure. Pumps and Compressors were also considered. Maintenance and mitigation devices are in place that would mitigate the risks of release from pumps and compressors. Vessel overfilling is mitigated administratively. The storage tanks are filled only to a maximum of 85% of the total capacity to allow expansion of the product.

Emergency Response Plan

Though the site is classified as a non-responding facility, it maintains an Emergency Action Plan (EAP), complying with state of Tennessees regulations. Both plans include procedures for notification of the local fire, law enforcement, and medical organizations. Notification of potentially affected neighbors would be coordinated through the fire department or law enforcement after consultation with site personnel. Should an actual incident occur, the plans five guidance to employees on how to respond if it is a minor problem and easily controlled on site. Larger emergencies require assistance from the local emergency response organizations and employees are knowledgeable as to when that outside assistance is required.

The EAP is reviewed periodically to ensure that it remains up-to-date, reflecting curren

t activities on-site and employees are trained on their responsibilities in an emergency to ensure prompt response should a situation arise. The EAP is based upon the following guidelines and standards:

1.	NPGA LP-Gas Safety Handbooks: Guidelines for Developing Plant Emergency Procedures and how to Control LP-Gas Leaks and Fires.
2.	OSHAs Occupational Safety and Health Standards for General Industry, specifically: 29 CFR 1910.38, Emergency Action Plans, 29 CFR 1910.39, Fire Prevention Plans, 29 CFR 1910.119, Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals, and 29 CFR 1910.120, Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response.
3.	National Fire Protection Association Guidelines, NFPA 58, Liquified Petroleum Gas Code and NFPA 54, National Fuel Gas Code.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

The facility has no plans at the present time to make any changes.
